title: How to Make Fried Chicken with Buttermilk and Tarragon

steps.headline: Place chicken pieces in a glass or stoneware bowl.
steps.description: Pour enough buttermilk into the bowl to cover chicken, and proceed to add a little mustard and tarragon. Cover and  refrigerate for at least three hours.

steps.headline: Remove chicken pieces from the buttermilk mixture and dredge in flour.
steps.description: Shake off the excess flour and place chicken pieces on a platter.

steps.headline: In a cast iron skillet, melt enough Crisco to fill the skillet 1/3 full.
Add chicken to the hot Crisco.
steps.description: Be careful not to crowd the pieces. Crowding will prevent pieces from cooking uniformly.

steps.headline: Watch the temperature of the Crisco.
steps.description: If it is too hot, the outside of the chicken will cook rapidly, while the inside will not be thoroughly cooked.

steps.headline: Turn pieces once during cooking.
steps.description: The chicken is done when, it becomes golden and crispy. Test one piece to see if chicken is done. Use a sharp knife to make a cut next to the bone. If juices run clear, the chicken is done.

steps.headline: Remove chicken from skillet, place on absorbent paper towels before serving.
Wait for the chicken to cool down, then serve!

text: Place chicken pieces in a glass or stoneware bowl. Pour enough buttermilk into the bowl to cover chicken, and proceed to add a little mustard and tarragon. Cover and  refrigerate for at least three hours. Remove chicken pieces from the buttermilk mixture and dredge in flour. Shake off the excess flour and place chicken pieces on a platter. In a cast iron skillet, melt enough Crisco to fill the skillet 1/3 full.  Melt Crisco on medium setting.  Add chicken to the hot Crisco. Be careful not to crowd the pieces. Crowding will prevent pieces from cooking uniformly. Watch the temperature of the Crisco. If it is too hot, the outside of the chicken will cook rapidly, while the inside will not be thoroughly cooked. Turn pieces once during cooking. The chicken is done when, it becomes golden and crispy. Test one piece to see if chicken is done. Use a sharp knife to make a cut next to the bone. If juices run clear, the chicken is done. Remove chicken from skillet, place on absorbent paper towels before serving.  Wait for the chicken to cool down, then serve!
